headline: Opinion: Carney is a PM governing like he’s got a crisis he doesn’t want to waste - The Globe and Mail
context: Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a news conference at the National Press Theater in Ottawa, on May 2.Dave Chan/The Globe and Mail

annotations.paragraph: There was no paring back plans to fit the bandwidth of minority government.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Carney's approach to governance.

annotations.paragraph: Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled his “immediate priorities” and the list was long, including fiscal discipline, a tax cut and removal of internal trade barriers by Canada Day, renegotiating the relationship with the country’s main partner, and “the biggest transformation of our economy since the end of the Second World War.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph lists Carney's priorities, which are central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Next up, Donald Trump at the White House on Tuesday.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a brief mention of an upcoming event without additional context.

annotations.paragraph: The trip isn’t a big surprise, in the sense that Mr. Carney kept saying through the recent campaign that he’d meet Mr. Trump right after the election.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Carney's planned meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: But remarkably, Mr. Carney offered no whiff of a postelection pause after the mad rush that made him PM, no scaling back his agenda to squeeze it through a minority Parliament, and no tamping down the crisis rhetoric about transforming Canada’s economy while negotiating with the U.S. Full speed ahead.
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights Carney's determination to pursue his agenda without pause.

annotations.paragraph: He said he’ll move fast on transforming the economy so Canada doesn’t have to rely on a quick deal. His short-term list of to-dos included “nation-building projects,” increasing productivity, reducing government waste and driving investment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about Carney's economic plans and priorities.

annotations.paragraph: “We’re going to focus on that while we have these negotiations with the Americans,” Mr. Carney said. “And if the negotiations with the Americans take longer, so be it. We’ve got more than enough to do.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Carney about his approach to negotiations and priorities.

annotations.paragraph: Naysayers might point out that a) his list of economy-shaping goals won’t be quick and easy and b) the business community is antsy about the prospect that negotiations with the U.S. might take “longer,” and not really in a “so-be-it” mood.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on potential criticisms and concerns regarding Carney's plans.

annotations.paragraph: Still, Mr. Carney is doing Negotiation 101 by trying to establish an alternative to a negotiated agreement. Politically, he is also making room to govern by keeping the crisis rhetoric high. It’s a big agenda in a hurry.
annotations.reason: This paragraph analyzes Carney's political strategy and approach to governance.

annotations.paragraph: The classic question for Canadian prime ministers who win minority governments is whether they will try to govern as though they have a majority – that is, as though they don’t have to make deals for the approval of smaller parties in the Commons.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides general context about governing in a minority government, not directly related to Carney's actions.

annotations.paragraph: On Friday, Mr. Carney made it clear that he’s going to govern like he has got a crisis – and it is one that he doesn’t want to waste.
annotations.reason: Introduces the main premise of Carney's approach to governance.

annotations.paragraph: He said he has a strong mandate, despite a minority government, because everyone knows the mission. People know what he ran on, he said, suggesting everyone should be able to get behind it now, in a crisis. King Charles III will come to open Parliament because, well, there’s a crisis.
annotations.reason: Provides Carney's justification for his approach and mentions a significant event.

annotations.paragraph: Wisely, he wasn’t talking about governing like he has a majority. He promised to work across party lines, with provinces and Indigenous people, business and labour. He said he spoke to Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre and promised to trigger a quick by-election so he could get a seat in the Commons. “No games,” he said. That’s the right tone for a crisis.
annotations.reason: Details Carney's strategy and interactions with political figures.

annotations.paragraph: It’s hard to tell how long it will last. So far, Mr. Carney’s style seems different.
annotations.reason: Provides vague commentary on Carney's style without new information.

annotations.paragraph: At his first sit-down news conference at the National Press Theatre, Mr. Carney was practised and prepared but, by the standards of modern scripted PMs, relatively unguarded.
annotations.reason: Describes Carney's demeanor at a news conference, adding context to his approach.

annotations.paragraph: There were moments when he was asked a question – for example, when asked what Mr. Trump wants from negotiations with Canada – when he appeared to be thinking over the answer rather than rifling through a mental file for a prepared line.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into Carney's approach and demeanor during a press conference, relevant to his leadership style.

annotations.paragraph: When a reporter asked if his affable and unabashedly ambitious Finance Minister, François-Philippe Champagne, would remain in the same post, Mr Carney replied: “Did he ask you to ask that question?”
annotations.reason: This paragraph highlights Carney's interaction with the press and his handling of questions, relevant to his leadership style.

annotations.paragraph: He didn’t answer all the questions, however. He dodged a query about whether his team is trying to lure NDP and Conservative MPs across the floor so his Liberals, having won 168 seats, could government with a majority. Politics goes on, even in crisis.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Carney's political strategy and actions, directly related to the article's focus on his governance.

annotations.paragraph: Make no mistake, Mr. Carney plans to use this crisis. He opened his news conference saying he’s “in politics to do big things, not to be something.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from Carney about his intentions, relevant to the article's theme of his governance approach.

annotations.paragraph: For someone who’s still a rookie prime minister, that’s a bit of risky bravado. But Mr. Carney is telling us he thinks he has an opportunity to govern bold and fast and he doesn’t want to miss it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers analysis of Carney's approach and ambition, relevant to the article's focus on his leadership style.
